title: FASHION
description:
The photographs in FASHION were made by Mark Power over a period of 27 years and across 23 countries. They were taken at construction sites, factories, quarries, shipyards, foundries, recycling facilities, theatres and other locations where things are being made, or fashioned.
Please note, the book weighs nearly 3kg and so postage costs are higher than usual to account for this.
specs:
Published December 2025
285 x 199 mm
520pp, 287 images
Hardback
ISBN 978-1-80598-000-1

title: An Extremely Un-Get-Atable Place
description:
‘It’s an extremely un-get-atable place, but it’s a nice house and I think I can make it quite comfortable with a little trouble.’—George Orwell
An Extremely Un-get-atable Place is a lyrical reimagining of the time that writer George Orwell lived at Barnhill, a remote farmhouse on the Isle of Jura in Scotland. It was here that Orwell wrote his landmark book Nineteen Eighty-Four—a dire warning of the dangers of totalitarianism and political despotism. Photographer Craig Easton was invited to stay at Barnhill—largely unchanged since Orwell’s time—where he made a series of landscape and still life images. In Easton’s new book, these photographs are presented alongside extracts from Orwell’s letters and diaries written on the island.
specs:
Published December 2025
Text by Richard Blair
270 x 330 mm
100pp, 58 images

title: Flowers for Bea
description:
Flowers for Bea is a book of still life photographs of wildflowers collected close to artist Brendan Barry’s home in Devon. The images were created in a camera obscura—a room sized camera, operated from the inside—using two distinct analogue processes. The creation of each photograph involved a painstaking process of alchemy and patience with a successful exposure sometimes taking up to 8 hours. 
A video showing Barry’s process can be viewed here.
specs:
Published December 2025
292 x 350 mm
88pp, 48 images
Hardback
